subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: Anthony: I agree totally with you that the ligatures have nothing to do with a changed sound.  They are simply easy and quick ways to write these vowels that
messageBody:
Anthony:

I agree totally with you that the ligatures have nothing to do with a changed sound.  They are simply easy and quick ways to write these vowels that combine with "r."

And hearing someone's accent is cool if if it is not 100% correct or as exact as an IPA transcription.

Finding it funny that there are two letters you don't use is like thinking it funny that the British pronounce words differently than Americans do.  A well designed alphabet should be able to map the major dialects of all the speakers of the language should it not?  Many English speakers no longer use the "hw" sound, but for those of us who do, a suggestion that it should be excluded from the alphabet will fall on deaf ears.

I must ask one question since you brought it up.  I understand that you substitute the vowel sound of "Ah" in place of the traditional "Awe" typically represented by "au," as in "nautical."  I first became really aware of this when a TV announcer in a frequently-aired commercial said "nautical" as if it were spelled "knotical," which left me confused as I did not understand why someone would pronounce a word whose spelling clearly seemed - at least to me - to indicate it was a diphthong as a short o sound.  What I am wondering is how do you pronounce the word "awe" itself as in what one experiences in connection with the deity?  Does that also come out as "ah"?  I have difficulty imagining someone saying, "I stand in ah before God."  To me that is the sound the doctor tells you to make before using a tongue depressor, not a separate word by itself.

I know this probably sounds parochial, but I have never had anyone answer this question before.  And if, in fact, people whose dialect has undergone this merger still pronounce the word "awe" as a stand-alone diphthong, why would they eschew it in other settings, such as "nautical."  The answer, I would suspect, is that English orthography is so hopelessly messed up that it causes no cognitive dissonance to pronounce the same letters one way in one word and quite differently in other words.  The average person doesn't even notice the problem.

Paige

Anthony Grahn wrote:

   Personally I like to think of Quickscript writing in a tape recorder metaphor with the reluctant exception of the senior standard spellings. Not every one follows this philosophy and they have good reason since there are certainly drawbacks. One rarely mentioned and irrelevant but hyper cool benefit though, is that you get to really hear the accent of the writer when you read the text. Something which never occurs with orthodox English.
   What to do with the ligatures is a good question I think. I believe they were conceived as a few connected forms to be used in junior. _We_ think of them as ligatures because we have an electo-typesetting bias. But the QM seems only to think of them a two letters joined for speed. IMO, I believe it might be best to view them as typcaster's  tools with pronunciation identical to the separate letters they represent.
  And what is the IPA pronunciation of each letter? Another great point. Attached is a phonetic correlation I put together to map the sounds as I think Read intended them. I did this by looking at the pronunciation of the examples and letter names as they were likely pronounced in his time and place which is to say I looked up each one of his words in the Oxford dictionary. Alas it does not exactly match my 21st cen west coast pronunciation either which in some cases is really annoying. In my personal speech "Ox", "Ah", and "Awe" are pronounced the same and having two letters in my alphabet that I never use (although others may) feels funny.


John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
othermale scripsit:

> Thus "eight" (name of a letter in QM) and
> "pair" (example used for a ligature in QM) have the same pronunciation
> in upper-class- British English but differ in 21st century American
> English.

I'm definitely American and 21st-century, and for me they are the same.
In terms of Wells lexical sets, SQUARE is like FACE but with an /r/,
rather than DRESS with an /r/.

--
John Cowan http://ccil. org/~cowan cowan@...

Eliot's Adam Bede, and Landor's Dialogues. --Somerset Maugham
